metadata.title: Rapid and Visible RPA-Cas12a fluorescence Assay for Accurate Detection of Zoonotic Dermatophytes

abstract.text: Background: Dermatophytosis is an infectious disease of global significance caused by several 22 fungal species, which affects the hair, nails, or superficial layers of the skin. The most common 23 zoonotic dermatophytes are Microsporum canis, Nannizzia gypsea and Trichophyton mentagrophytes. 24

Wood's lamp examination, microscopic identification and fungal culture are the main conventional 25 diagnostic methods used in clinics. Less common methods are dermatophyte PCR and 26 biopsy/histopathology. However, these methods also have limitations for providing both accuracy and 27 timely on-site detection. The recent development of CRISPR-based diagnostic platform provides the 28 possibility of a rapid, accurate, and portable diagnostic tool, which has huge potential for clinical 29

Objectives: The purpose of this study is to establish a molecular method for rapid and accurate 31 diagnosis of clinical dermatophytes, which can accelerate clinical diagnostic testing and help timely 32

Methods: In this paper, we design a Cas12a-based assay combined with recombinase polymerase 34 amplification (RPA) to differentiate three main zoonotic dermatophytes. The limit of detection (LOD) 35 is determined by using standard strains. A total of 25 clinical samples (hair and scurf) are identified to 36 evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of this assay. 37

The RPA-Cas12a method showed high sensitivity and specificity (100% and 100%, 38 respectively). The results could be observed directly by naked-eyes, and all tested samples were 39 consistent with fungal culture and sequencing results. 40 Conclusions: Compared with other methods, the RPA-Cas12a-fluorescence assay requires less time 41 (30 minutes) and less complicated equipment, and visible changes can be clearly observed, which is 42 suitable for on-site clinical diagnosis. 43 KEYWORDS 44 Dermatophytes, CRISPR-Cas12a, recombinase polymerase amplification, Microsporum canis, 45 Nannizzia gypsea, Trichophyton mentagrophytes 46

The sequences used for PCR and RPA primers design were obtained from the NCBI Nucleotide 137

Database (GenBank accession numbers were MH858319.1, NR_131265.1 and NR_131271. 1, 138 respectively). PCRs were performed by Q5 High-Fidelity DNA Polymerase (New England Biolabs, 139 Inc. USA) with the listed primers (Table 2 ) and 2 µL genome samples, following the program: 98 °C 140 for 30 s, then 35 cycles of 98 °C for 5 s, 58 °C for 10 s and 72 °C for 3s. Primers for RPA were listed 141 in Table 2 . RPA reactions were performed by the Twist-Amp basic kit (TwistDX, Britsh). Each RPA 142 reaction contained 29.5 µL rehydration buffer, 2.4 μL forward and reverse primers, 2 µL genome 143 samples, 2.5 μL of magnesium acetate (MgAc), and 11.2 μL water. The mixtures were incubated at 144 39℃ for 15 min. Then the RPA products were cleaned up using 70% ethanol precipitation method and 145 verified by electrophoresis on a 1% agarose gel. 146

A his-tagged (C-terminal) codon-optimized version of Cas12a (Francisella tularensis subsp. 148 novicida) gene was synthesized from Sangon Biotech (Shanghai, China). The expression plasmid 149 (pET28a-FnCas12a) was transformed into BL21 (DE3), then, BL21 (DE3) cells carrying the 150 expression plasmid were cultured in Luria-Bertani (LB) medium at 37 °C overnight. The cells were 151 transferred into fresh LB (1:100 inoculation) at 37 °C until OD600 reached 0.8. Then, induced with 152 0.5 mM IPTG and transferred to 18°C for 16-hour expression. Cells were collected by centrifugation 153 and resuspended in 50 mL of lysis buffer [50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.0), 1.5 M NaCl, 1 mM DTT and 5% 154 glycerol] with 1 mM phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride (PMSF) as the protease inhibitor and lysed by 155 high pressure. Then the lysis was centrifuged at 15000 g for 30 min and the supernatant was loaded onto HisTrap HP column (GE Healthcare, America). The column was then washed with wash buffer 157 (lysis buffer supplemented with 30 mM imidazole) and eluted with elution buffer (lysis buffer 158 supplemented with 600 mM imidazole). The collected protein was dialyzed in storage buffer (20 mM 159 Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 600 mM NaCl, 1 mM DTT, 0.2 mM EDTA, 15% (v/v) glycerol) and finally stored 160 in aliquots at -80 °C. 161
The preparation crRNA was proceeded in three steps. The transcription templates for crRNA 163 preparation were amplified by the PCR process, and the primers were list in Table 2

Cas12a cleavage reaction system contained 500 nM Cas12a, 500 nM crRNA, 2 µL target DNA, 170 500 nM ssDNA (FAM-GATCAAGAGCTA -BHQ1) and 0.5 µL RNase inhibitor (TaKaRa, Japan) in 171 a 20 µL volume. The reactions were performed at 37°C in NEB buffer 3.1 for 15 min, and the reaction 172 products in a volume of 10 μL were diluted 10 times to 100 μL and examined using EnSpire 173

Multimode Plate Reader (PerkinElmer, America). Then, the remaining reaction products were placed 174 under the blue light generated by Azure C300 Gel Imager (Azure Biosystems, America) for visual 175 inspection. 176

Internal transcribed spacer (ITS) region was selected for RPA-Cas12a detection, because of their 179 divergent sequences across different fungi species and high probability of identifying the fungi type. 180
body_text.section: Design and detection of crRNA guides and primers in CRISPR-Cas12a assay

body_text.text: Based on the sequence alignment of ITS1 regions, four crRNA guides were designed to identify the 181 three major dermatophytes infections in cats and dogs. A specific sequence was selected for crRNA 182 guide recognition of three main dermatophytes (crRNA-DM) and three specific sequences were 183 selected for crRNA guide recognition of three specific dermatophytes (crRNA-Ng, Tm, and Mc) (Fig.  184 2A). PCR amplification was performed with DNA extracted from the standard strains by using primer 185 set (PCR-F and PCR-R in Table 2 ) from fungal ITS1 region. The target products were amplified from 186 extracted DNA from all three strains (Fig. 2B) . The results indicated that Cas12a assay can detect nucleic acid products with a concentration as low 208 as 10-100 nM. 209

body_text.text: The case No. 25 diagnosed as non-dermatophytosis was collected as negative control. This patient 222 showed focal hair loss which was similar to the signs of dermatophytosis and the clinical diagnosis 223 result was non-dermatophytosis. We used the RPA-Cas12a fluorescence assay to detect clinical 224 samples, so that we can verify the specificity and sensitivity of this new rapid diagnostic method. The 225 fungal culture and sequencing were considered as standard results. 226

body_text.text: To evaluate our method, we initially tested our method using the first 6 clinical samples. The Dermatophyte PCR or qPCR is becoming more and more popular due to its sensitivity, but it is not 262 intuitive and more dependent on available laboratory conditions and the facilities, and the processing 263 time is about 2-3 hours. 264

body_text.text: Accurate and timely identification of fungal isolates are very important. All of these emphasizes 265 the actual need to develop new methods that provide rapid, intuitive and highly specific identification of dermatophytes. We developed an RPA-Cas12a detection method for dermatophytes, which showed 267 excellent results in our research. The results were 100% consistent with the traditional fungal culture 268 and ITS sequencing. We found that no matter what kinds of samples we use to extract DNA, such as 269 hair, scurf or the debris on the tape or cotton swab, the amount of extracted DNA was sufficient for 270 later Cas12a-based diagnosis. The Cas12a-based assay can detect as low as 10-100 nM PCR product, 271 which showed that the developed assay had high sensitivity. All the positive samples can be sorted Therefore, the method we designed can assist veterinarians in accurately diagnosing three main 284 dermatophytosis, especially when the operators are not yet proficient in the microscopic examination. 285

body_text.text: In our study, we only used 25 clinical cases for verification. Because of regional differences and 286 different pet-raising styles, there are relatively few cases of dermatophytosis in small animals caused 287 by N. gypsea and T. mentagrophytes, especially in cats 3 . Therefore, more specimens should be included in the experiment to evaluate the effectiveness in the future. 289
body_text.section: Design and detection of crRNA guides and primers in CRISPR-Cas12a assay

body_text.text: In conclusion, the RPA-Cas12a-fluorescence assay is a promising method for detecting 290 dermatophytes with high sensitivity and specificity. And this method can rapidly detect the 291 dermatophyte genome from clinical samples onsite, and adopt optimized steps to reduce the detection 292 time. Therefore, the RPA-Cas12a-fluorescence assay will be an excellent choice for point-of-care 293 dermatophytosis diagnosis.

Then, we applied three specific crRNAs for identification of 189 corresponding dermatophytes. The fluorescence detection using crRNA-Ng guide can specifically 190 identify N. gypsea, and compared with the negative control, it has reached a significant difference 191 (p<0.001). However, fluorescence detections of the remaining dsDNA products (T. mentagrophytes 192 and M. canis) were higher than the negative control, but they can't reach a significant difference 193 (p<0.001)(Fig. 3B). Therefore, we set the "p<0.001" as the detection standard and only significant 194 values (p<0.001) were marked with asterisks (***). The guides crRNA-Tm and crRNA-Mc also can 195 specifically identify T. mentagrophytes and M. canis, respectively with significant differences 196 (p<0.001)(Figs 3C and 3D). Under visual inspection, the target can produce obvious and specific 197 fluorescence in blue light(Figs 3E-3H).

FIGREF1.text: Sensitivity of the Cas12a-based fluorescence reporting system 199 In order to determine the limit of detection (LOD), different concentrations of dsDNA products 200 were participated in the Cas12a-based detection. Signals generated by the use of guides crRNA-Tm 201 and crRNA-Mc showed significant differences (p<0.001) between experiment groups with 10 nM 202 DNA concentration and the negative control(Figs 4A and 4B). Compared to the control, there were 203 no significant difference when the concentration of the samples was less than 10 nM(Figs 4A and 4B). 204In parallel, signals generated by the use of guides crRNA-DM and crRNA-Ng showed significant 205 values (p<0.001) by using 100 nM DNA concentration in statistical analysis, and there were no 206 significant differences when the concentration of the samples were less than 100 nM(Figs 4C and 4D). 207

FIGREF3.text: 227 crRNA-DM guide can detect fluorescence of 5 samples and identify them as dermatophytes infections, 228 which reached significant differences (p<0.001) except for sample No. 3 (Figs 6A and 6B). The 229 crRNA-Mc guide also detected obvious fluorescence in these 5 samples (Figs 6A and 6B). In addition, 230 crRNA-Ng and crRNA-Tm guides can not detect any fluorescence from these 6 samples. Then we 231 collected and tested more samples. Sample No. 7 to No. 24 were all identified as M. canis (Figs S1 232 and S2A). We were surprised about the results for sample No. 3, as it was initially diagnosed with 233 dermatophytosis in clinics. We inoculated all 25 clinical samples on SDA plate and incubated at 30℃ 234 for 2 weeks, and all samples were grown expect for negative control sample No. 25 (Figs 6C and 235 S2B). Then we performed micromorphology study and ITS sequencing using ITS1 and ITS4 as 236 primer set for these clinic isolates. After observing the macromorphology of fungal colony, 237 micromorphology of macroconidia and performing NCBI Blast of ITS sequencing, 23 samples 238 (except for samples No. 3) were identified as M. canis (Figs 6C and S2B). The RPA-Cas12a 239 fluorescence test matched the fungal culture and ITS sequencing results. The result of negative control 240 (No. 25 sample) was also consistent with the results of fungal culture and clinical diagnosis (Fig. 241 S2B). After statistical analysis, RPA-Cas12a method can achieve 100% sensitivity and 100% 242 specificity (Table 3). The main colony of sample No. 3 in the medium was sequenced and identified 243as Chaetomium globosum, which is a saprophytic fungus (not dermatophytes). 2444 | DISCUSSION245At present, the identification of dermatophytes in small animals still relies on comprehensive 246 diagnosis methods, such as Wood's lamp examination and microscopy in clinical practice. Some 247 clinics can perform fungal culture and dermatophyte PCR for further diagnosis. However, not every 248 clinic has relative equipment that can be used and the fungal culture will delay the diagnosis for about249 1-2 weeks. Actually, there is no gold standard diagnostic test for dermatophytosis. 3 Every diagnosis 250 method used clinically has its own limitations. For example, hair loss, scaling, crusting and erythema 251 are the most common clinical lesions. Due to the variability of the lesions, pruritus and other lesions 252 may occur in different animals. Moreover, it also can be confused with other diseases such as 253 pemphigus foliaceus. As for Wood's lamp examination, only 50% of M. canis infections can be 254 detected with fluorescence, while other dermatophytes (such as N. gypsea or M. persicolor 32 ) do not 255 produce fluorescence. 33 It can cause confusion and inaccuracy at the same time. 2 Direct microscopic 256 examination may be a simple and rapid way to screen for microconidia and hyphae, however, 257 only >85% of cases can be accurately diagnosed. 3 In addition, the professional requirements for 258 microscopic examination are very high. Two recognized disadvantages of fungal culture are 259 time-consuming and demanding (about 1-2 weeks), which can delay the diagnostic outcome and 260 treatment. Molecular tools are increasingly used in the laboratory for the fungal identification.261
